channel.title: NYT > Science
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Parasitic Queen: Now She’s Stealing an Ant Fief
item.description: Experts discovered an unusual form of regicide in which a parasitic ant queen tricks workers in a colony into turning on their own mother.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Dzombak

item.title: A Voyage Into the Art of Finding One’s Way at Sea
item.description: Scientists and Indigenous sailors in the Marshall Islands are studying seafaring and the human brain.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil

item.title: We Can Now Track Individual Monarch Butterflies. It’s a Revelation.
item.description: Scientists used tiny new sensors to follow the insects on journeys that take thousands of miles to their winter colonies in Mexico.
item.dc:creator: Dan Fagin and Jonathan Corum
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times

item.title: Video Reveals How Far Wolves Will Go to Steal a Meal
item.description: After a wolf dragged a crab trap out of water to get a snack, some scientists said the behavior revealed their ability to use tools.
item.dc:creator: Lesley Evans Ogden

item.title: Hochul Urged to Ban Horseshoe Crab Fishing
item.description: Supporters of the legislation argue it would protect a declining horseshoe crab population, while opponents warn it will harm the commercial fishing industry.
item.dc:creator: Jon Hurdle
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: If Gov. Kathy Hochul signs the bill, New York would join New Jersey and Connecticut in stopping the fishing industry from using the crabs as bait for catching other marine species, including the endangered American eel.

item.title: Almost Everything About NASA’s ESCAPADE Mission to Mars Is Unusual
item.description: The ESCAPADE mission, which launched to space on a Blue Origin rocket on Thursday, breaks the mold of how planetary science missions typically come together.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang

item.title: Blue Origin Lands Booster After Rocket Launch and Matches SpaceX’s Feat
item.description: The lower half of the New Glenn rocket set down on a platform in the Atlantic Ocean after lifting a small NASA Mars mission to space.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: A screengrab from the live feed of the Blue Origin launch showing the returned booster rocket on the floating platform Jacklyn in the Atlantic Ocean.

item.title: The Dogs of 8,000 B.C. Were Amazingly Diverse
item.description: The staggering array of modern dog breeds is typically traced to the Victorian era. But half of all canine variation was in place roughly 10,000 years ago, a new study suggests.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: Bird Flu Ravaged the World’s Largest Elephant Seal Population, Study Finds
item.description: After the H5N1 virus hit the remote island of South Georgia in 2023, more than 50,000 breeding females may have disappeared.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: In Nebraska, Makeovers for Buildings That Don’t Price Out the Locals
item.description: In a struggling area of Lincoln, a program pays for repairs and energy efficiency upgrades in rental buildings. In return, landlords must keep rents affordable.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley and Arin Yoon
item.media:credit: Arin Yoon for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Freedom Comes to My Mind’: Saving Family Legacy and Land in South Carolina
item.description: Conservation can be tough when a property is passed down informally over generations with no clear title. A growing effort is helping families sort it all out.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn and Nora Williams
item.media:credit: Nora Willams For The New York Times

item.title: Driving an E.V. Across North Dakota? Thank the Standing Rock Tribe.
item.description: A tribally owned network of chargers will soon be complete, connecting reservations and bridging a gap in the Midwest.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey and Jaida Grey Eagle
item.media:credit: Jaida Grey Eagle for The New York Times

item.title: In Washington, Birds Are Giving ‘Yelp Reviews’ of Forest Restoration Work
item.description: A collective of land trusts, conservancies and tribes is capturing birdsong with audio gear and A.I. for clues about habitat health.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley and Meron Menghistab
item.media:credit: Meron Menghistab for The New York Times

item.title: Iowa City Made Its Buses Free. Traffic Cleared, and So Did the Air.
item.description: Ridership jumped, people cut back on driving and, over the summer, the city extended the program another year.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley and Annick Sjobakken
item.media:credit: Annick Sjobakken for The New York Times

item.title: Frustrated With Your Home Insurer? Tell Us About It.
item.description: Help us track trends in the home insurance market by filling out this survey.
item.dc:creator: Mira Rojanasakul and Claire Brown
item.media:credit: Emily Kask for The New York Times

item.title: Environmentalists Sue to Stop Oil Lease Sales in the Gulf of Mexico
item.description: A Trump administration proposal to allow more exploration for oil and gas violates environmental laws, the groups said.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.category: Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Regulation and Enforcement
item.media:description: An oil operation in the Gulf of Mexico.

item.title: Greenpeace Faces an Unusual New Legal Attack From a Pipeline Giant
item.description: The company that won a huge verdict against Greenpeace earlier this year has asked a North Dakota court to block a countersuit in the Netherlands.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:description: Protesting the Dakota Access Pipeline project near Cannonball, N.D., in September 2016. Earlier this year a court found Greenpeace liable for its role in demonstrations there.

item.title: Study Analyzes How Much ‘Macro’ Plastic Is Deadly to Sea Life
item.description: Scientists analyzed thousands of autopsies of seabirds, sea turtles and marine mammals and found that even small amounts of ingested plastic can be deadly.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.category: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
item.media:description: An autopsied Hawksbill sea turtle in a lab in the United Arab Emirates. Lying beside the turtle are items removed from its stomach, including a large amount of plastic.

item.title: A Plan for Private Jet Taxes Would Fund Climate Measures
item.description: A small group of countries is aiming to impose a fee on private jets and premium commercial fares. The revenue would help nations adapt to warming.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:description: A private jet at the Farnborough International Airshow last year. Aviation accounts for roughly 4 percent of greenhouse gas emissions.

item.title: A Day at the Beach Hunting Mammoths
item.description: “Citizen paleontologists” can keep the fossils they uncover around Europe’s largest port. All the professionals ask is that those amateurs let them know.
item.dc:creator: Nina Siegal and Ilvy Njiokiktjien
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times

item.title: Thousands March for Climate Action as COP30 Talks Enter Second Week
item.description: As the talks continue, some countries are pushing for a detailed “road map” for a global transition away from oil, gas and coal.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman, Brad Plumer and Max Bearak
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: A demonstration near the U.N. climate summit in Belém, Brazil, on Saturday. The atmosphere has been a marked contrast to the past three summits that were held in countries where governments restricted public protests.

item.title: How Many People Die in India From Hot Weather? Nobody Really Knows.
item.description: Officials have yet to grasp the magnitude of heat-related deaths, let alone effectively deal with the problem, public health experts and scientists say.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das
item.media:credit: Anindito Mukherjee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Commuters drinking water from canisters placed near a bus stand during a heat wave in Rajasthan, India, in June.

item.title: Wheelchair? Hearing Aids? Yes. ‘Disabled’? No Way.
item.description: Many older Americans shun an identity that could bring helpful accommodations, improve care and provide community.
item.dc:creator: Paula Span

item.title: Overlooked No More: Sabina Spielrein, Visionary Lost Between Freud and Jung
item.description: She maintained a triangular correspondence with the two men, who overshadowed the significant contributions she made to the field of psychoanalysis.
item.dc:creator: Nina Siegal

item.title: F.D.A. Sharply Limits Use of Drug Linked to Two Teen Deaths
item.description: A gene therapy for Duchenne muscular dystrophy caused complications to the liver, prompting a review of its use for younger patients.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett
item.media:description: The drug Elevidys has been central to the business model of Sarepta Therapeutics, a publicly traded company that is worth about $2 billion.

item.title: Judge to Approve Purdue Pharma Bankruptcy, Releasing Billions for Opioid Plaintiffs
item.description: Under the plan, the company will dissolve and its owners, members of the Sackler family, will pay as much as $7 billion of their personal fortune to states, localities, tribes and others harmed in the opioid crisis.
item.dc:creator: Jan Hoffman
item.media:description: The bankruptcy plan for Purdue Pharma, the maker of OxyContin, is the largest settlement with a single pharmaceutical company throughout years of the national opioid litigation.

item.title: How to Watch the Leonids Meteor Shower Reach Its Peak
item.description: The moon is far from full this weekend, which could mean good fireball viewing for night sky watchers.
item.dc:creator: Katrina Miller
item.media:description: The Leonid meteor shower viewed from North Macedonia in November 2020.

item.title: Indigenous People Take the Stage at COP30 Climate Talks in Belém, Brazil
item.description: This summit is unlike any of its predecessors in at least one significant way: The Indigenous presence is palpable and strong.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta, Brad Plumer and David Gelles
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: An Indigenous rights demonstration on Thursday in Belém, Brazil. The snake in the background was a prop with a meaning.

item.title: RFK Jr. Walks a Tightrope on Trump Deal for Obesity Drugs
item.description: The weight loss medicines are proving to be a test case for Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the health secretary, in straddling divisions between his supporters and the president.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum and Rebecca Robbins
item.media:description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the health secretary, appearing in the Oval Office on Nov. 6 with other health officials, the chief executives of Novo Nordisk and Eli Lilly and others.

item.title: Sharon Camp, Mother of the ‘Plan B’ Contraceptive Pill, Dies at 81
item.description: An advocate for women’s reproductive health, she started one of the world’s smallest pharmaceutical companies to bring an emergency birth-control method to market.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green
item.media:credit: Marty Katz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sharon Camp in 2000. One of the many obstacles to bringing the morning-after pill to the United States, she said, was the pharmaceutical industry, which “demonstrated the political instincts of celery.”

item.title: Trump Administration Revokes Biden Ban on Drilling and Mining in Alaska Wilderness
item.description: The decision to allow oil and gas drilling in Alaska’s ecologically sensitive North Slope has the support of the state’s governor and senators.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: Caribou near a pipeline on the north slope of Alaska in 2023.

item.title: Infant Formula Company Tied to Botulism Outbreak Had Known Problems
item.description: A Pennsylvania plant run by the company, ByHeart, was shut down this year after inspectors found mold, a leaking roof and more than 2,500 dead insects in a food production area.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett and Julie Creswell
item.media:description: Ron Belldegrun and Mia Funt, the two founders of ByHeart, during a ribbon-cutting at plant in Reading, Pa., in 2022.

item.title: The Global Climate Leadership Vacuum
item.description: The United States is largely absent from the United Nations climate negations in Brazil. So who is stepping up?
item.dc:creator: Claire Brown
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: A lobby of the COP30 United Nations climate summit in Belém, Brazil.

item.title: Northern Lights Are Beautiful, but for Satellites They’re Risky
item.description: At least one space launch has been put on hold, as satellite operators and rocket companies manage the effects of the current geomagnetic storm hitting Earth.
item.dc:creator: Katrina Miller

item.title: Greenhouse Gas Emissions Head for a Record in 2025, Global Carbon Project Reports
item.description: But there are signs that greenhouse gas pollution in China might be slowing, according to a new analysis.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: A coal-fired power plant in Candiota, in southeastern Brazil.

item.title: How to See the Northern Lights on Wednesday
item.description: A geomagnetic storm made the aurora borealis visible across a swath of the United States again on Wednesday, illuminating the skies as far south as Arizona.
item.dc:creator: Nazaneen Ghaffar and Amy Graff
item.media:credit: Matterhorn Ski Paradise and Feratel/UGC, via Reuters
item.media:description: The northern lights shine in the night sky in Valtournenche, Italy, on Wednesday.

item.title: At the Cybathlon, May the Best Brain-Computer Interface Win
item.description: Every four years at the Cybathlon, teams of researchers and technology “pilots” compete to see whose brain-computer interface holds the most promise.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang
item.media:credit: Francesca Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Collumb training at the University of Bath.

item.title: Visiting Leiden, Canals and Charm Without the Crowds of Amsterdam
item.description: Leiden, a city whose university is often called the Oxford of the Netherlands, features museums, gardens, murals and plenty of ways to stretch your mind.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lucas and Desiré Van Den Berg
item.media:description: The De Valk Windmill Museum, along the Rijnsburgersingel canal, in Leiden.

item.title: Scientists Grow More Hopeful About Ending a Global Organ Shortage
item.description: At an international conference, researchers at the forefront of animal-human transplantation compared notes and allowed themselves the first real optimism in decades.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Kevin Serna for The New York Times
